p: Sympathetic innervation ( via noradrenaline) acts as inhibitory feedback modulating the release of ACh in the myenteric plexus ( via presynaptic α 2-adrenergic receptors coupled to Gi/Go), and also by its action on receptors present in the intestinal smooth muscle ( via post receptorsβ 2-adrenergic synaptic coupled to Gs)[ 48]. Both actions result in inhibition of peristaltic activity and decreased tone of intestinal smooth muscle, leading to reduced intestinal motility[ 49]. Therefore, a blockade of pre or postsynaptic receptors can increase intestinal transit.
